docs.snippet: Marje Fields, a longtime talent agent who was a pioneer in placing well-known actors in television commercials, died on Jan. 27 at her home in Manhattan. She was 77.    Among the clients represented at one time by her agency, Marje Fields Inc., we...
docs.lead_paragraph: Marje Fields, a longtime talent agent who was a pioneer in placing well-known actors in television commercials, died on Jan. 27 at her home in Manhattan. She was 77. Among the clients represented at one time by her agency, Marje Fields Inc., were John Travolta, Ted Danson, Nancy Walker, Edward Hermann, Barry Bostwick and Hal Linden. While Ms. Fields, whose married name was Karp, concentrated on the television advertising, side of the business, others in her office also represented some of their clients for theatrical productions.
docs.abstract: Marge Fields, longtime talent agent, dies at age 77 (S)

headline.main: Marje Fields, 77; Talent Agent Put Stars in TV Ads

docs.snippet: Barbie was rehearsing her lines yet again, gesturing and smiling in a glittering fantasy showroom inhabited by workmen who were too desperately busy to listen. ''This year,'' she was saying, ''we have Barbie and Ken featured as Dana Scully and Fox...
docs.lead_paragraph: Barbie was rehearsing her lines yet again, gesturing and smiling in a glittering fantasy showroom inhabited by workmen who were too desperately busy to listen. ''This year,'' she was saying, ''we have Barbie and Ken featured as Dana Scully and Fox Mulder of 'The X-Files.' It's the first time Barbie and Ken have been featured as F.B.I. agents!'' A designer, pushing a paint roller to touch up a wall in Barbie white, never looked up. An electrician took no notice. Barbie surveyed the room after completing her spiel and shook her head. ''Got to get this on the tip of my tongue before show time,'' said Barbie, a New York actress whose real name is Jeanne Jones.
docs.abstract: American International Toy Fair, most prestigious trade show of $20 billion toy industry, will open in New York City on Feb 9; there are expected to be 20,000 buyers from 50 countries and 1,695 exhibitors from 23 countries at fair; for first five days, exhibits will be held in city's 430 toy showrooms and in Toy Center on Fifth Avenue; then fair, which is not open to public, will continue at Jacob K Javits Convention Center for four more days; map; photos (M)

headline.main: Break a (Bendable) Leg, Barbie!; It's Show Time for a Cast of Thousands at the Toy Fair

docs.snippet: American Movie Classics, the cable network devoted to the golden age of Hollywood film, begins its observance of Black History Month on Tuesday with the television premiere of ''Small Steps, Big Strides: The Black Experience in Hollywood (1903-197...
docs.lead_paragraph: American Movie Classics, the cable network devoted to the golden age of Hollywood film, begins its observance of Black History Month on Tuesday with the television premiere of ''Small Steps, Big Strides: The Black Experience in Hollywood (1903-1970).'' While it notes the distorted images that characterized black actors' early roles in movies and inhibited their portrayals long afterward, this hourlong special is primarily a celebration of the struggle waged by black performers for unbiased representation. The program focuses on the personalities and talents of these early black actors, their incremental gains and their more spectacular performances in Hollywood films. Among the highlights are clips of the work of such stars as Stepin Fetchit, Bill (Bojangles) Robinson, the Nicholas Brothers, Lena Horne, Paul Robeson, Harry Belafonte, Dorothy Dandridge and Sidney Poitier, as well as sketches of their careers.
docs.abstract: American Movie Classics cable network observes Black History Month with program Small Steps, Big Strides: The Black Experience in Hollywood (1903-1970); program celebrates the struggle waged by black performers to shed stereotyped representation; photos (M)

headline.main: Stepping Out of Stereotype, in Style

docs.snippet: Dana Tang, a daughter of Oscar L. Tang of New York and the late Frances Young Tang, was married last evening to Andrew Haid Darrell, the son of Henriette and Norris Darrell of Cold Spring Harbor, N.Y. Judge Adlai S. Hardin Jr. of the Federal Bankr...
docs.lead_paragraph: Dana Tang, a daughter of Oscar L. Tang of New York and the late Frances Young Tang, was married last evening to Andrew Haid Darrell, the son of Henriette and Norris Darrell of Cold Spring Harbor, N.Y. Judge Adlai S. Hardin Jr. of the Federal Bankruptcy Court in White Plains officiated on Vail Mountain in Colorado. The bride, 33, is an architectural designer at Richard Gluckman Architects in New York. She was a lecturer in Asian languages and literature at Colorado College in Colorado Springs from 1990 to 1991. She graduated from the University of Colorado and received a master's degree in East Asian studies from Harvard University and a second master's, in architecture, from Yale University.

docs.snippet: THE fashion victims were crossing the King's Road in their wide-bottomed pants, their high-heeled sneakers, their velvet-trimmed cardigans. On his way to lunch, Manolo Blahnik, the high priest of the high heel, spotted his bete noire: a young woma...
docs.lead_paragraph: THE fashion victims were crossing the King's Road in their wide-bottomed pants, their high-heeled sneakers, their velvet-trimmed cardigans. On his way to lunch, Manolo Blahnik, the high priest of the high heel, spotted his bete noire: a young woman wobbling along in heavy, clunky platform shoes of the sort that members of the rock group Kiss might have worn in their heyday. ''Don't ask me about that!'' he exclaimed, shuddering dramatically. ''I hate that 70's platform look! It makes me vomit! Maybe for a rock-and-roll star, but for everyone else . . .'' His voice trailed off. ''Ugh! That's my pet hate.''
docs.abstract: Article profiles successful career of shoe designer Manolo Blahnik; Blahnik is to receive special Stiletto Award from Council of Fashion Designers of America in recognition of his nearly three decades of making inimitable women's footwear; photo (M)

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: COUNCIL OF FASHION DESIGNERS OF AMERICA

docs.snippet: Gila Ivey and Christopher Joseph Selicious were married last evening at the George Washington Manor in Roslyn, N.Y. Rabbi Irwin Lowenheim performed the ceremony.    The bride, 30, is an administrative law judge for the New York State Office of Tem...
docs.lead_paragraph: Gila Ivey and Christopher Joseph Selicious were married last evening at the George Washington Manor in Roslyn, N.Y. Rabbi Irwin Lowenheim performed the ceremony. The bride, 30, is an administrative law judge for the New York State Office of Temporary and Disability Assistance in Manhattan. She graduated from the State University at Albany and Tulane University Law School. The bride, who changed her surname, is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gershon Itzikowitz of Brooklyn.

docs.snippet: WHEN we arrived with our guests at Wellingtons in Huntington, we were greeted offhandedly by the hostess and ushered to a well-napped table in the narrow dining room to the left of the bar.     The restaurant opened in Huntington six months ago, a...
docs.lead_paragraph: WHEN we arrived with our guests at Wellingtons in Huntington, we were greeted offhandedly by the hostess and ushered to a well-napped table in the narrow dining room to the left of the bar. The restaurant opened in Huntington six months ago, after an eight-year stint in Bridgeport. The new premises held promise, although the menu was less reassuring, full of old standbys like veal Marsala and grilled chicken Dijon. But there were a few newcomers, and we began with several of them. Before ordering, we listened to a long, detailed recitation of specials by our scowling waiter. His unsmiling countenance put a damper on our meal whenever he surfaced, interrupting conversation gracelessly to recite the dessert list, abruptly appearing to ask if we wanted coffee and to slap the (unrequested) check on the table.
docs.abstract: Patricia Brooks reviews Wellingtons restaurant in Huntington, NY (M)

headline.main: Portions Suitable for Athletes in Training

docs.snippet: The way baseball people see it, the Arizona Diamondbacks last week exercised Phase I of their acquisition of Bernie Williams. Phase II will come at the end of the coming season, when they actually sign him as a free agent.    ''There clearly is a ...
docs.lead_paragraph: The way baseball people see it, the Arizona Diamondbacks last week exercised Phase I of their acquisition of Bernie Williams. Phase II will come at the end of the coming season, when they actually sign him as a free agent. ''There clearly is a lot of talking about that,'' said a baseball official who is in a position to hear the talk. ''I don't know if it's true or not true, but a lot of people have mentioned it.''
docs.abstract: Baseball Notebook article focuses on speculation that Arizona Diamondbacks signed free-agent pitcher Andy Benes to win favor with his agent, Scott Boras, who also represents New York Yankees outfielder Bernie Williams, in hopes of signing Williams next year; photos (M)

headline.main: Benes Now, Williams Later: All Part of Great Conspiracy Theory
